Ordinary Bitter.clarity: Chill haze is allowable at cold temperatures
Ordinary Bitter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium residual malt sweetness should be present
Ordinary Bitter.fermentation_characteristics: Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity esters are acceptable. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at low levels.
Ordinary Bitter.additional_notes: When using these guidelines as the basis for evaluating entries at competitions, competition organizers may choose to create subcategories which reflect English and American hop character.

Special Bitter or Best Bitter.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Special Bitter or Best Bitter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium residual malt sweetness should be present
Special Bitter or Best Bitter.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to medium at the brewer’s discretion
Special Bitter or Best Bitter.fermentation_characteristics: Low carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity esters are acceptable. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at low levels.
Special Bitter or Best Bitter.additional_notes: When using these guidelines as the basis for evaluating entries at competitions, competition organizers may choose to create subcategories which reflect English and American hop character.

Extra Special Bitter.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Extra Special Bitter.fermentation_characteristics: Low carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. The overall impression is refreshing and thirst quenching. Fruity esters are acceptable. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at low levels.
Extra Special Bitter.additional_notes: Entries in this subcategory exhibit hop aroma and flavor attributes typical of traditional English hop varieties.

Scottish-Style Light Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Scottish-Style Light Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malty, caramel aroma may be present. A low to medium-low, soft and chewy caramel malt ﬂavor should be present.
Scottish-Style Light Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for lightly carbonated draft versions. Fruity esters, if present, are low.
Scottish-Style Light Ale.additional_notes: These beers differ significantly from Scotch Ale, especially regarding original gravity, alcohol content, and malt attributes. While there are conflicting theories as to whether traditional Scottish Light Ale exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many examples with peat smoke character present at low to medium-low levels. Peat smoke attributes may be absent or present at low to medium-low levels. Versions exhibiting higher levels of smoke character are categorized as Smoke Beer.

Scottish-Style Heavy Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Scottish-Style Heavy Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malty, caramel aroma is present. The style exhibits a medium degree of sweet malt and caramel. The overall impression is smooth and balanced.
Scottish-Style Heavy Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for lightly carbonated draft versions. Fruity esters, if present, are low.
Scottish-Style Heavy Ale.body: Medium with a soft chewy character
Scottish-Style Heavy Ale.additional_notes: These beers differ significantly from Scotch Ale, especially regarding original gravity, alcohol content, and malt attributes. While there are conflicting theories as to whether traditional Scottish Heavy Ale exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many examples with peat smoke character present at low to medium-low levels. Peat smoke attributes may be absent or present at low to medium-low levels. Versions exhibiting higher levels of smoke character are categorized as Smoke Beer.

Scottish-Style Export Ale.color: Medium amber to dark chestnut brown
Scottish-Style Export Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Scottish-Style Export Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Sweet malt and caramel aromas and flavors define the character of a Scottish Export
Scottish-Style Export Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters, if present, are low. Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for lightly carbonated draft versions.
Scottish-Style Export Ale.additional_notes: These beers differ significantly from Scotch Ale, especially regarding original gravity, alcohol content, and malt attributes. While there are conflicting theories as to whether traditional Scottish Export Ale exhibited peat smoke character, the current marketplace offers many examples with peat smoke character present at low to medium-low levels. Peat smoke attributes may be absent or present at low to medium-low levels. Versions exhibiting higher levels of smoke character are categorized as Smoke Beer.

English-Style Summer Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
English-Style Summer Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Residual malt sweetness is low to medium. Torriﬁed or malted wheat is often used in quantities of 25 percent or less. Malt attributes such as biscuity or low levels of caramel are present.
English-Style Summer Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium, expressed as floral, herbal, earthy, stone fruit, citrus or other attributes. Hop ﬂavor should not be assertive and should be well balanced with malt character.
English-Style Summer Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity esters are low to medium. Diacetyl and DMS should not be present.
English-Style Summer Ale.additional_notes: The overall impression is refreshing and thirst quenching

Classic English-Style Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Classic English-Style Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium malt aroma and ﬂavor is present. Low caramel character is allowable.
Classic English-Style Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-low to medium-high, expressed as ﬂoral, herbal, earthy, stone fruit or other attributes.
Classic English-Style Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are medium to medium-high. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.

British-Style India Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
British-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium malt ﬂavor should be present
British-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to high, expressed as ﬂoral, herbal, earthy, stone fruit or other attributes from high hopping rates.
British-Style India Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are medium to high. Traditional interpretations are characterized by medium to medium-high alcohol content. The use of water with high mineral content results in a crisp, dry beer with a subtle and balanced character of sulfur compounds. Diacetyl can be absent or may be present at very low levels.
British-Style India Pale Ale.additional_notes: A wide range of hop varieties may be used for bitterness or for approximating traditional English hop character. The use of water with high mineral content may result in a crisp, dry beer rather than a malt-accentuated version.

Strong Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Strong Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to high malt and caramel sweetness. Very low levels of roast malt may be present.
Strong Ale.perceived_bitterness: Present but minimal, and balanced with malt ﬂavors.
Strong Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Rich, often sweet and complex fruity ester attributes can contribute to the profile of Strong Ales. Alcohol types can be varied and complex. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.
Strong Ale.additional_notes: When using these guidelines as the basis for evaluating entries at competitions, competition organizers may choose to split this category into subcategories which reflect strong and very strong versions.

Old Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Old Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Fruity esters can enhance and complement the malt aroma and ﬂavor proﬁle. Old Ales have malt and sometimes caramel sweetness.
Old Ale.perceived_bitterness: Present but minimal, and balanced with malt flavors.
Old Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters can contribute to the character of these beers. Alcohol types can be varied and complex. A distinctive quality of Old Ales is that they undergo an aging process, often for years. Aging can occur on their yeast either in bulk storage or through conditioning in the bottle. This contributes to a rich, wine-like, and often sweet, oxidized character. Complex estery attributes may also emerge. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.
Old Ale.additional_notes: Low level attributes typical of wood aging such as vanillin are acceptable. Brettanomyces and acidity reﬂect historical character; low level attributes such as horsey, goaty, leathery, phenolic, etc. and acidity may be present and balanced with other ﬂavors. Attributes arising from liquids previously aged in a barrel, such as bourbon or sherry, should not be present. Beers that exhibit such attributes are categorized as wood- and barrel-aged beers.

English-Style Pale Mild Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
English-Style Pale Mild Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt ﬂavor and aroma dominate the ﬂavor proﬁle
English-Style Pale Mild Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels. Fruity esters are very low to medium-low.

English-Style Dark Mild Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
English-Style Dark Mild Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt attributes such as caramel, licorice, roast or others may be present in aroma and flavor.
English-Style Dark Mild Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels. Fruity esters are very low to medium-low.

English-Style Brown Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
English-Style Brown Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Roast malt may contribute to a biscuit or toasted aroma proﬁle. Roast malt may contribute to the ﬂavor proﬁle. Malt profile can range from dry to sweet.
English-Style Brown Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium-low level fruity esters are appropriate. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.

Brown Porter.color: Dark brown to very dark. May have red tint.
Brown Porter.clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive clarity. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
Brown Porter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium malt sweetness. Caramel and chocolate attributes are acceptable. Strong roast barley or strong burnt or black malt character should not be present.
Brown Porter.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are acceptable. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at low levels.

Robust Porter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to medium-high. Malty sweetness, roast malt, cocoa and caramel should be in harmony with bitterness from dark malts.
Robust Porter.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters should be present and balanced with all other characters. Diacetyl should not be present.

Sweet Stout or Cream Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to medium-high. Malt sweetness, chocolate and caramel should contribute to the aroma and should dominate the ﬂavor proﬁle. Roast ﬂavor may be present. Low to medium-low roasted malt-derived bitterness should be present.
Sweet Stout or Cream Stout.perceived_bitterness: Low to medium-low and serves to balance and suppress some of the sweetness without contributing apparent ﬂavor and aroma
Sweet Stout or Cream Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters, if present, are low. Diacetyl should not be present.
Sweet Stout or Cream Stout.body: Full-bodied. Body can be increased with the addition of milk sugar (lactose).

Oatmeal Stout.clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
Oatmeal Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Coffee, caramel, roasted malt, or chocolate aromas should be prominent. Roasted malt character of caramel or chocolate should be smooth without bitterness.
Oatmeal Stout.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Optional, but if present should not upset the overall balance.
Oatmeal Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Oatmeal is used in the grist, resulting in a pleasant, full ﬂavor without being grainy. Fruity esters are not present to very low. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.

Scotch Ale or Wee Heavy.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Scotch Ale or Wee Heavy.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Scotch Ales are aggressively malty with a rich and dominant sweet malt aroma and ﬂavor. A caramel character is often part of the proﬁle. Dark roasted malt ﬂavors may be present at low levels.
Scotch Ale or Wee Heavy.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters, if present, are generally at low levels. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at low levels.
Scotch Ale or Wee Heavy.additional_notes: Pleasant, low-level oxidation is acceptable in Scotch Ales. Examples exhibiting more prevalent oxidation are categorized as Aged Beer.

British-Style Imperial Stout.color: Ranging from dark copper typical of some historic examples, to very dark more typical of contemporary examples
British-Style Imperial Stout.clarity: Opaque in darker versions. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
British-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Extremely rich malty ﬂavor, often expressed as toffee or caramel, and may be accompanied by very low roasted malt astringency.
British-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to medium, with ﬂoral, citrus or herbal qualities.
British-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_bitterness: Medium and should not overwhelm the overall balance. The bitterness may be higher in darker versions while maintaining balance with sweet malt.
British-Style Imperial Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters can be medium to high. Diacetyl should not be present.
British-Style Imperial Stout.additional_notes: This style was also originally called ‘Russian Imperial Stout’.

British-Style Barley Wine Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
British-Style Barley Wine Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Hop aroma and ﬂavor are very low to medium. English type hops are often used but are not required for this style.
British-Style Barley Wine Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Complexity of alcohols and fruity ester attributes are often high and balanced with the high alcohol content. Low levels of diacetyl are acceptable. Low carbonation is acceptable in this style. Caramel and some oxidized character (vinous aromas or ﬂavors) may be considered positive attributes.

Irish-Style Red Ale.clarity: Chill haze or yeast haze may be present at low levels
Irish-Style Red Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium candy-like caramel malt sweetness should be present in ﬂavor. A toasted malt character should be present, and there may be a slight roast barley or roast malt presence.
Irish-Style Red Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low level fruity esters are acceptable. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.

Classic Irish-Style Dry Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: The prominence of coffee-like roasted barley and a moderate degree of roasted malt aroma and flavor deﬁnes much of the character. The hallmark dry-roasted attributes typical of Dry Stout result from the use of roasted barley. Initial malt and light caramel ﬂavors give way to a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the ﬁnish.
Classic Irish-Style Dry Stout.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: European hop character may range from not present to low in aroma and ﬂavor
Classic Irish-Style Dry Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low relative to malt and roasted barley as well as hop bitterness. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels. Slight acidity may be present but is not required.

Export-Style Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Initial malt and light caramel ﬂavors give way to a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the ﬁnish.
Export-Style Stout.perceived_bitterness: May be analytically high, but the perception is lessened by malt sweetness.
Export-Style Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels. Slight acidity is acceptable.

Golden or Blonde Ale.clarity: Chill haze should not be present
Golden or Blonde Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low malt sweetness and toast, cereal-like or other pale malt attributes should be present in ﬂavor and aroma at low to medium-low levels.
Golden or Blonde Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Hop aroma and ﬂavor should be very low to medium, with attributes typical of hops of any origin present but not dominant.
Golden or Blonde Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters may be present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl and DMS should not be present.
Golden or Blonde Ale.body: Low to medium with a crisp finish

Session India Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
Session India Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: A low to medium maltiness may be present in aroma and ﬂavor but varies with underlying style.
Session India Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Hop aroma and ﬂavor are medium to high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes. Overall hop character is assertive.
Session India Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low to medium. Diacetyl should not be present.
Session India Pale Ale.additional_notes: Session India Pale Ales are lower alcohol versions of any of the various American, Juicy or Hazy, British or other India Pale Ale styles from around the world. Balance and high drinkability are key to a successful Session India Pale Ale. Hop aroma and flavor attributes hew to the underlying India Pale Ale style being made at lower strength. Beers exceeding 5.0% abv are not considered Session India Pale Ales. Beers under 5.0% abv (4.0% abw) which meet the criteria for another classic or traditional style category are not considered Session India Pale Ales. An India Pale Ale made to alcohol content below 0.5% abv (0.4% abw) is categorized as a Non-Alcohol Malt Beverage.

American-Style Amber/Red Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
American-Style Amber/Red Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-high to high maltiness with low to medium caramel character
American-Style Amber/Red Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes
American-Style Amber/Red Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters, if present, are low.

American-Style Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
American-Style Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low caramel malt aroma is allowable. Low to medium maltiness may include low caramel malt character.
American-Style Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High, exhibiting a wide range of attributes including ﬂoral, citrus, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur, diesel-like, onion-garlic, catty, piney, resinous, and many others.
American-Style Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters may be low to high. Diacetyl should not be present.

Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.clarity: Can vary widely from very low haze to very high degree of cloudiness. Starch, yeast, hop, protein or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-low malt aroma and flavor may be present
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-high to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, exhibiting a very wide range of attributes, especially fruity, tropical, juicy, and many others.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. The impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Medium-low to medium-high fruity esters are present and can contribute to the perception of sweetness and be complementary to the hop profile. Diacetyl should not be present.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.body: Medium-low to medium-high. Perceived silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.additional_notes: Grist may include oats, wheat, or other adjuncts to promote haziness. The term ‘juicy’ is frequently used to describe taste and aroma attributes often present in these beers which result from late, often very large, additions of hops. A juicy character is not required, however. Other hop-derived attributes such as citrus, pine, spice, floral or others may be present with or without the presence of juicy attributes. Likewise the term ‘hazy’ is frequently used to describe the appearance of many examples of these beers. However, some versions may exhibit very low cloudiness.
Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale.bitterness_ibu: 5-30; may differ significantly from perceived bitterness

American-Style Strong Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
American-Style Strong Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low caramel malt aroma is allowable. Low level maltiness may include low caramel malt character.
American-Style Strong Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to very high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes including ﬂoral, citrus, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur, diesel-like, onion-garlic, catty, piney, resinous, and many others.
American-Style Strong Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters may be low to high. Diacetyl should not be present.

Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.clarity: Can vary widely from very low haze to very high degree of cloudiness. Starch, yeast, hop, protein or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-low malt aroma and flavor may be present
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-high to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, exhibiting a very wide range of attributes, especially fruity, tropical, juicy, and many others.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. The impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Medium-low to medium-high fruity esters may be present and can contribute to the perception of sweetness and be complementary to the hop profile. Diacetyl should not be present.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.body: Medium-low to medium-high. A silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.additional_notes: Grist may include oats, wheat, or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Lactose may be used to enhance body and balance. Lactose should not lend to, or overwhelm, the flavor character of these beers. The term ‘juicy’ is frequently used to describe taste and aroma attributes often present in these beers which result from late, often very large, additions of hops. A juicy character is not required, however. Other hop-derived attributes such as citrus, pine, spice, floral or others may be present with or without the presence of juicy attributes. Likewise the term ‘hazy’ is frequently used to describe the appearance of many examples of these beers. However, some versions may exhibit very low cloudiness. These beers can exhibit astringency and heat (sometimes referred to as ‘hop burn’) as a result of very high hop usage rates and excessive contact time in beer, which can detract from balance and drinkability when present above low levels.
Juicy or Hazy Strong Pale Ale.bitterness_ibu: 15-40; may differ significantly from perceived bitterness

American-Style India Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
American-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-low to medium intensity malt attributes are present in aroma and ﬂavor
American-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to very high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes including ﬂoral, piney, citrus, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur, diesel-like, onion-garlic, catty, resinous, and many others.
American-Style India Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low to high. Diacetyl and DMS should not be present.
American-Style India Pale Ale.additional_notes: The use of water with high mineral content may result in a crisp, dry beer rather than a malt-accentuated version. Sugar adjuncts may be used to enhance body and balance. Hops of varied origins may be used for bitterness or for approximating traditional American character. Any use of thiolized yeasts, terpene blends or any other advanced hop products should not overwhelm the beer and should be in harmony with overall flavor profile. Versions of this style brewed with non-traditional yeasts, fruits, spices, or other flavorings are categorized as Experimental India Pale Ales. Versions of this style brewed with darker malts, may be categorized as Experimental India Pale Ales, or possibly as American-Style Black Ale.

Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.clarity: Can vary widely from very low haze to very high degree of cloudiness. Starch, yeast, hop, protein or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-low malt aroma and flavor may be present
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, exhibiting a very wide range of attributes, especially fruity, tropical, juicy, and many others.
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. The impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Medium to medium-high fruity esters are present, and can contribute to the perception of sweetness and be complementary to the hop profile. Diacetyl should not be present.
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.body: Medium-low to medium-high. A silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.additional_notes: Grist may include oats, wheat, or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Lactose may be used to enhance body and balance. Lactose should not lend to, or overwhelm, the flavor character of these beers. The term ‘juicy’ is frequently used to describe flavor and aroma attributes often present in these beers which result from late, often very large, additions of hops. A juicy character is not required, however. Other hop-derived attributes such as citrus, pine, spice, floral or others may be present with or without the presence of juicy attributes. Likewise the term ‘hazy’ is frequently used to describe the appearance of many examples of these beers. However, some versions may exhibit very low cloudiness. These beers may sometimes exhibit astringency and/or heat (often referred to as ‘hop burn’) as a result of very high hop usage rates and excessive contact time in beer, which can detract from balance and drinkability when present above low levels. Any use of thiolized yeasts, terpene blends or any other advanced hop products should not overwhelm the beer and should be in harmony with overall flavor profile
Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale.bitterness_ibu: 20-50; may differ significantly from perceived bitterness

American-Belgo-Style Ale.clarity: Should conform the base beer style
American-Belgo-Style Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Typically low. Perception of specialty or roasted malts or barley can be very low to robust in darker versions.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to very high, exhibiting American-type hop aromas not usually found in traditional Belgian styles.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.perceived_bitterness: Medium to high, in alignment with base beer style.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are medium to high. Belgian yeast attributes such as banana, berry, apple, coriander, spice or smoky-phenolic should be in balance with malt and hops. Diacetyl, sulfur, and attributes typical of Brettanomyces should not be present.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.body: Medium-low to medium, in alignment with base beer style.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.additional_notes: American-Belgo-Style Ales are either 1) non-Belgian beer types portraying the unique characters imparted by yeasts typically used in big, fruity Belgian-style ales, or 2) deﬁned Belgian-style beers displaying the hallmark attributes typical of American variety hops. These beers are unique unto themselves.
American-Belgo-Style Ale.color_srm: Varies with style(Varies with style EBC)

American-Style Brown Ale.color: Deep copper to very dark brown
American-Style Brown Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
American-Style Brown Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium levels of roasted malt, caramel, and chocolate aromas and flavors should be present.
American-Style Brown Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-low to high. Hop flavor and aroma should be in balance with and never dominate malt aroma or flavor attributes.
American-Style Brown Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium-low fruity esters may be present. Diacetyl should not be present.

American-Style Black Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-low caramel malt and dark roasted malt aromas and ﬂavors are present. Astringency and burnt character of roast malt should be absent.
American-Style Black Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-high to high, with fruity, citrusy, piney, ﬂoral, herbal or other aromas derived from hops of all origins.
American-Style Black Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low to medium. Diacetyl should not be present.
American-Style Black Ale.additional_notes: Black ales that do not meet the specifications for American-Style Black Ale may possibly be categorized as Experimental India Pale Ale.

American-Style Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Low to medium malt sweetness with any of caramel, chocolate, or roasted coffee attributes present at low to medium levels, with a distinct dry-roasted bitterness in the ﬁnish. Astringency from roasted malt and roasted barley is low. Slight roasted malt acidity is acceptable.
American-Style Stout.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to high, often with any of citrusy, resiny or other attributes typical of many American hop varieties.
American-Style Stout.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.

American-Style Imperial Porter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: No roast barley or strong burnt/black malt character should be present. Medium malt, caramel, and cocoa sweetness should be present.
American-Style Imperial Porter.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are present but not overpowering and should complement hop character and malt-derived sweetness. Diacetyl should not be present.

American-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Extremely rich malty aroma is typical. Extremely rich malty ﬂavor with full sweet malt character is typical. Roasted malt astringency and bitterness can be moderate but should not dominate the overall character.
American-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium-high to high, exhibiting any of ﬂoral, citrus, herbal, or any other attributes typical of American hops.
American-Style Imperial Stout.perceived_bitterness: Medium-high to very high and balanced with rich malt character.
American-Style Imperial Stout.fermentation_characteristics: High Alcohol content is evident. Fruity esters can be high. Diacetyl should not be present.

Double Hoppy Red Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Double Hoppy Red Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to medium-high caramel malt character should be present in ﬂavor and aroma. Low to medium biscuit or toasted malt character may also be present.
Double Hoppy Red Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Hop aroma is high, derived from any variety of hops. Hop ﬂavor is high and balanced with other beer attributes.
Double Hoppy Red Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Alcohol content is medium to high. Complex alcohol ﬂavors may be present. Fruity esters are medium. Diacetyl should not be present.

Imperial Red Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Imperial Red Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to high caramel malt character is present in aroma and ﬂavor
Imperial Red Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High, derived from any variety of hops. Hop ﬂavor is prominent and balanced with other beer attributes.
Imperial Red Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Very high alcohol is a hallmark of this style. Complex alcohol ﬂavors may be present. Fruity esters are medium. Diacetyl should not be present.

American-Style Imperial or Double India.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Haze created by dry hopping is allowable at any temperature.
American-Style Imperial or Double India.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium pale malt character is typical. Low pale caramel malt character may be present.
American-Style Imperial or Double India.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to intense, exhibiting a wide range of attributes including ﬂoral, piney, citrus, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit, and other), sulfur, diesel-like, onion-garlic, catty, resinous, and many others. Hop character should be fresh and evident, and should not be harsh.
American-Style Imperial or Double India.fermentation_characteristics: Alcohol content is medium-high to high and evident. Fruity esters are medium to high. Diacetyl should not be present.
American-Style Imperial or Double India.additional_notes: This style of beer should exhibit the fresh character of hops. Oxidized or aged character should not be present. Versions brewed with darker malts, non-traditional yeasts, fruits, spices, or other flavorings are categorized as Experimental India Pale Ale.

Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.clarity: Can vary widely from very low haze to very high degree of cloudiness. Starch, yeast, hop, protein or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium malt aroma and flavor may be present
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to intense, exhibiting a very wide range of attributes, especially fruity, tropical, juicy, and many others.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. The impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance, and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.fermentation_characteristics: Medium-high to high fruity esters are present, and can contribute to the perception of sweetness and be complementary to the hop profile. Diacetyl should not be present.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.body: Medium to high. A silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.additional_notes: Grist may include oats, wheat, or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Lactose may be used to enhance body and balance. Lactose should not lend to, or overwhelm, the flavor character of these beers. The term ‘juicy’ is frequently used to describe taste and aroma hop-derived attributes often present in these beers which result from late, often very large, additions of hops. A juicy character is not required, however. Likewise the term ‘hazy’ is frequently used to describe the appearance of many examples of these beers. However, some versions may exhibit very low cloudiness. Other hop-derived attributes such as citrus, pine, spice, floral or others may be present with or without the presence of juicy attributes. These beers may sometimes exhibit astringency and/or heat (often referred to as ‘hop burn’) as a result of very high hop usage rates and excessive contact time in beer, which can detract from balance and drinkability when present above low levels. Versions of this style brewed with darker malts, non-traditional ale yeasts, fruits, spices, or other flavorings are categorized as Experimental India Pale Ale.
Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India P.bitterness_ibu: 30-80; may differ significantly from perceived bitterness

American-Style Barley Wine Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
American-Style Barley Wine Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Caramel or toffee malt aroma attributes are often present. High residual malty sweetness, often exhibiting caramel or toffee attributes, should be present.
American-Style Barley Wine Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to very high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes.
American-Style Barley Wine Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Complex alcohols are evident. Fruity esters are often high. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.
American-Style Barley Wine Ale.additional_notes: Vinous, sherry-like, or port-like attributes arising from oxidation may be considered positive when in harmony with overall flavor profile. Low carbonation may be acceptable in this style.

American-Style Wheat Wine Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
American-Style Wheat Wine Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Any of bready, wheat, honey or caramel malt aroma and flavor attributes are often present. High residual malt sweetness should be present.
American-Style Wheat Wine Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are often high and balanced by a complexity of alcohols and high alcohol content. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels. Phenolic yeast character, sulfur, and DMS should not be present. Oxidized, stale, and aged attributes are not typical of this style.
American-Style Wheat Wine Ale.additional_notes: This style is brewed with at least 50% wheat malt.

Smoke Porter.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Smoked porters will exhibit mild to assertive smoke malt aroma and flavor in balance with other aroma attributes. Black malt character can be present in some porters, while others may be absent of strong roast character. Roast barley character is absent to low depending on underlying porter style being smoked. Medium to high malt sweetness with caramel or chocolate flavor attributes is acceptable.
Smoke Porter.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium fruity esters are acceptable
Smoke Porter.additional_notes: When using these guidelines as the basis for evaluating entries at competitions, brewers may be asked to provide supplemental information about entries in this category to allow for accurate evaluation of diverse entries. Such information should include the traditional style of porter as well as the wood type used as a smoke source (e.g. ‘alder smoked brown porter’).
Smoke Porter.color_srm: Varies with porter style(Varies with porter style EBC)

American-Style Sour Ale.clarity: Chill haze, bacteria, and yeast-induced haze is acceptable at any temperature.
American-Style Sour Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low. In darker versions, any of roasted malt, caramel, or chocolate aroma and flavor attributes should be present at low levels.
American-Style Sour Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Moderate to intense, yet balanced, fruity esters are present. Diacetyl, DMS, and Brettanomyces should not be present. The evolution of natural acidity at medium-low to high levels develops a balanced complexity and is expressed as a refreshing, pleasant sourness, in harmony with other attributes. The acidity present is usually in the form of lactic, acetic, and other organic acids naturally developed with acidiﬁed malt in the mash or in kettle or post wort fermentation and is produced by various microorganisms including certain bacteria and yeasts. Acidic character can be a complex balance of several types of acid and attributes of age. Wood vessels may be used during the fermentation and aging process, but wood-derived ﬂavors such as vanillin should not be present. There should be no residual ﬂavors from liquids previously aged in a barrel such as bourbon or sherry.
American-Style Sour Ale.additional_notes: Beers exhibiting wood-derived characters or characters of liquids previously aged in wood are categorized as Wood-Aged Sour Beer. Fruited versions are categorized elsewhere.
American-Style Sour Ale.color_srm: May vary widely(May vary widely EBC)

American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.color: Can range from pale to black depending on underlying beer style and is often influenced by the color of added fruit
American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.clarity: Chill haze, bacteria, and yeast-induced haze is acceptable at any temperature.
American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low. In darker versions, any of roasted malt, caramel, or chocolate aroma and flavor attributes should be present at low levels.
American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.perceived_bitterness: None to high and in balance with fruit character
American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Moderate to intense, yet balanced, fruity esters are present. Diacetyl, DMS, and Brettanomyces should not be present. The evolution of natural acidity at medium-low to high levels develops a balanced complexity and is expressed as a refreshing, pleasant sourness, in harmony with other attributes. The acidity present is usually in the form of lactic, acetic, and other organic acids naturally developed with acidiﬁed malt in the mash or in kettle or post wort fermentation and is produced by various microorganisms, including certain bacteria and yeasts. Acidic character can be a complex balance of several types of acid and attributes of age. Wood vessels may be used during the fermentation and aging process, but wood-derived ﬂavors such as vanillin should not be present. Attributes arising from liquids previously aged in a barrel, such as bourbon or sherry, should not be present.
American-Style Fruited Sour Ale.additional_notes: Fruit aromas, ranging from subtle to intense, should be present. Fruit or fruit extracts, used as an adjunct in either the mash, kettle, primary or secondary fermentation, provide harmonious fruit character ranging from subtle to intense. Beers exhibiting wood-derived attributes or evidence of liquids previously aged in wood are categorized as Fruited Wood-Aged Sour Beer. Within the framework of these guidelines, coconut is deﬁned as a vegetable, and beers containing coconut are categorized as Field Beer. Likewise beers containing chili peppers are categorized as Chili Beer. Fruited versions of Berliner-Style Weisse and Belgian-Style Sour Ale are categorized elsewhere.

American-Style Fruit Beer.color: Can range from pale to very dark depending on the underlying style and is often influenced by the color of added fruit
American-Style Fruit Beer.perceived_bitterness: In balance with fruit character and usually at very low to medium levels
American-Style Fruit Beer.fermentation_characteristics: American-Style Fruit Beers are fermented with traditional German, British or American ale or lager yeast. Beers fermented with Belgian-style, German-style Hefeweizen or other South German wheat beer or Berliner-style Weisse yeasts should be categorized elsewhere. Fruit beers exhibiting sourness should be categorized elsewhere. Attributes typical of wild fermentation should not be present.
American-Style Fruit Beer.additional_notes: Fruit aromas, ranging from subtle to intense, should be present and should not be overpowered by hop aromas. Fruit or fruit extracts, used as an adjunct in either the mash, kettle, primary or secondary fermentation, provide harmonious fruit character ranging from subtle to intense. Some beers may fit into this category if they contain fruity adjuncts but no actual fruit (i.e. Hibiscus or similar ingredients that impart a fruity flavor). Within the framework of these guidelines, coconut is deﬁned as a vegetable, and a beer containing coconut is categorized as Field Beer. Likewise beers containing chili peppers are categorized as Chili Beer. Fruit beers fermented with Belgian yeast (Wit, Abbey, Farmhouse, Saison, or Brettanomyces) should be categorized as Belgian-Style Fruit Beers, or possibly as fruited Brett Beers. Fruit Beers with 30%+ wheat are categorized as Fruit Wheat Beers. All of the various IPA styles brewed with Fruit are categorized as Experimental IPA. All fruited Sour Beers are categorized elsewhere. All fruited Wood- and Barrel-Aged beers (sour or not) are categorized elsewhere.
American-Style Fruit Beer.color_srm: 5-50 or color of fruit(10-100 or color of fruit EBC)

West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.clarity: Chill haze or hop haze is acceptable at low levels
West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium-low. Caramel or roasted malt character should not be present
West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: High to very high, exhibiting a wide range of attributes including floral, piney, citrus, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur, diesel-like, catty, resinous and many others.
West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.perceived_bitterness: Medium to very high, but not harsh
West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters range from low to medium. DMS, acetaldehyde, and diacetyl should not be present. These beers are characterized by a high degree of attenuation.
West Coast-Style India Pale Ale.additional_notes: These beers are highly attenuated with an assertive hop character and a dry, crisp finish. Versions brewed with darker malts, non-traditional yeasts, fruits, spices, or other flavorings are categorized as Experimental India Pale Ale. Any use of thiolized yeasts, terpene blends or any other advanced hop products should not overwhelm the beer and should be in harmony with overall flavor profile

German-Style Koelsch.clarity: Chill haze should not be present
German-Style Koelsch.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt character is very low to low with soft sweetness. Caramel character should not be present.
German-Style Koelsch.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low and, if present, should express noble hop character.
German-Style Koelsch.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are absent to low, expressed as pear, apple, or wine-like attributes when present. Diacetyl should not be present.
German-Style Koelsch.body: Low to medium-low. Dry and crisp.
German-Style Koelsch.additional_notes: The Koelsch style is originally from the Köln area. Traditional examples often display persistent head retention. Small amounts of wheat can be used in brewing beers of this style. Koelsch-style beers are fermented at warmer temperatures than is typical for lagers, but at lower temperatures than most English and Belgian-style ales. They are aged cold. Ale yeast is used for fermentation. Lager yeast is sometimes used for bottle conditioning or ﬁnal cold conditioning.

German-Style Altbier.clarity: Clear to slightly hazy. Chill haze should not be present
German-Style Altbier.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: A variety of malts contributes to medium-low to medium malt aroma and flavor. Toast aroma typical of Munich malts should be present. Slight nuttiness is acceptable. Roast malt character should be present at low levels and well-integrated with the overall malt profile. Smoke character should not be present.
German-Style Altbier.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium with hop flavor more perceptible than aroma, with attributes typical of traditional German noble hops.
German-Style Altbier.perceived_bitterness: Medium to high, producing a clean dry finish.
German-Style Altbier.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are absent to low, with attributes expressed subtly as citrus, pear, dark cherry or plum. A slight sulfur aroma is acceptable. Diacetyl should not be present.
German-Style Altbier.additional_notes: The Altbier style is originally from the Dusseldorf area. The overall impression is clean, crisp and ﬂavorful with a dry ﬁnish.

Berliner-Style Weisse.color: Straw to pale. These are the lightest of all the German wheat beers.
Berliner-Style Weisse.clarity: May appear hazy or cloudy from yeast or chill haze
Berliner-Style Weisse.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are low to medium. Diacetyl should not be present. Brettanomyces character may be absent or present at low to medium levels and, if present, may be expressed as any of horsey, goaty, leathery, phenolic, fruity, or acidic aroma and flavor attributes. The unique combination of yeast and lactic acid bacteria fermentation yields a beer that is acidic and highly attenuated.
Berliner-Style Weisse.additional_notes: Carbonation is high. Traditionally, some Berliners were brewed or served with fruit, spices, or syrups. Some more contemporary versions have been brewed with other ingredients such as darker malts. Any such versions will take on corresponding hues, and may exhibit flavor and aroma attributes typical of such ingredients.

Leipzig-Style Gose.clarity: Clear to hazy. Haze may or may not be from yeast.
Leipzig-Style Gose.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt sweetness and attributes are not present to very low
Leipzig-Style Gose.fermentation_characteristics: Medium to high lactic acid character should be present and expressed as a sharp, refreshing sourness. These beers are not excessively aged.
Leipzig-Style Gose.additional_notes: These beers typically contain malted barley and unmalted wheat, with some versions also containing oats. Salt (table salt) and coriander may be present in low amounts. A Gose brewed with fruit(s), spices (other than salt or coriander), darker malts or other ingredients is categorized as Contemporary-Style Gose. Carbonation is high to very high. Effervescent.

Contemporary-Style Gose.color: Usually straw to medium amber and can take on the color of added fruits or other ingredients such as darker malts.
Contemporary-Style Gose.clarity: Clear to hazy. Haze may or may not result from yeast
Contemporary-Style Gose.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt aroma and flavor is not present to very low
Contemporary-Style Gose.fermentation_characteristics: Horsey, leathery, or earthy aromas contributed by Brettanomyces yeasts may be present but at low levels as these beers do not undergo prolonged aging. Contemporary Gose may be fermented with pure beer yeast strains, or with yeast mixed with bacteria. Alternatively, they may be spontaneously fermented. Low to medium lactic acid character is present in all examples expressed as a sharp, refreshing sourness.
Contemporary-Style Gose.additional_notes: Contemporary-Style Gose may be brewed with malted or unmalted barley, wheat, and oats. Contemporary examples may also contain other grains. As in traditional examples, low level salt (table salt) and coriander additions may or may not be present in Contemporary Gose. Attributes from the use of a wide variety of herbs, spices, ﬂowers, fruits, or other ingredients not found in traditional Leipzig-Style Gose may also be present and in harmony with overall flavor profile.

South German-Style Hefeweizen.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
South German-Style Hefeweizen.fermentation_characteristics: Medium-low to medium-high fruity and phenolic attributes are hallmarks of this style. Phenolic attributes such as clove, nutmeg, smoke, and vanilla are present. Banana ester aroma and ﬂavor should be present at low to medium-high levels. Diacetyl should not be present.
South German-Style Hefeweizen.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent malted wheat, and are very highly carbonated. These beers are typically (though not always) roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a characteristically fuller, creamier mouthfeel.

South German-Style Kristal Weizen.clarity: Clear with no chill haze present. Because the beer is ﬁltered, no yeast should be present.
South German-Style Kristal Weizen.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt sweetness is very low to medium-low
South German-Style Kristal Weizen.fermentation_characteristics: The aroma and flavor are very similar to Hefeweizen with the caveat that fruity and phenolic characters are not combined with the yeasty ﬂavor and fuller-bodied mouthfeel of yeast. The phenolic characteristics are often described as clove-like or nutmeg-like and can be smoky or even vanilla-like. A Banana-like ester aroma and flavor is often present. Diacetyl should not be present. Kristal Weizen is well attenuated and very highly carbonated.
South German-Style Kristal Weizen.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent malted wheat. They have no yeast ﬂavor, and exhibit a cleaner, drier mouthfeel than counterparts served with yeast.

German-Style Leichtes Weizen.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
German-Style Leichtes Weizen.fermentation_characteristics: The phenolic and estery aromas typical of Weissbiers should be present but less pronounced in this style. The overall ﬂavor proﬁle is less complex than Hefeweizen due to a lower alcohol content and there is less yeasty ﬂavor. Diacetyl should not be present.
German-Style Leichtes Weizen.body: Low with a lighter mouthfeel than Hefeweizen. The German word ‘leicht’ means light, and as such these beers are light versions of Hefeweizen.
German-Style Leichtes Weizen.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and, when yeast is present, will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Wei.color: Amber to light brown. The German word ‘Bernsteinfarben’ means amber colored.
South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Wei.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Wei.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Distinct sweet maltiness and caramel or bread-like character arises from the use of medium-colored malts.
South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Wei.fermentation_characteristics: The phenolic and estery aromas and flavors typical of Weissbiers are present but less pronounced in Bernsteinfarbenes Weissbiers. These beers should be well attenuated and very highly carbonated. Diacetyl should not be present.
South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Wei.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. It is often roused during pouring, and, when yeast is present, will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

South German-Style Dunkel Weizen.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy
South German-Style Dunkel Weizen.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Distinct sweet maltiness and a chocolate-like character from dark or roasted malts exemplify beer in this style. Dark barley malts are frequently used along with dark Cara or color malts.
South German-Style Dunkel Weizen.fermentation_characteristics: The phenolic and estery aromas and flavors typical of Weissbiers are present but less pronounced in Dunkel Weissbiers. Dunkel Weissbiers should be well attenuated and very highly carbonated. Diacetyl should not be present
South German-Style Dunkel Weizen.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and, when yeast is present, will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a characteristically fuller mouthfeel.

South German-Style Weizenbock.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
South German-Style Weizenbock.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium malty sweetness should be present. If dark, a mild roast malt character should emerge in the flavor and, to a lesser degree, in the aroma.
South German-Style Weizenbock.fermentation_characteristics: Balanced, clove-like phenolic and fruity ester banana notes produce a well-rounded ﬂavor and aroma. Diacetyl should not be present. Carbonation should be high.
South German-Style Weizenbock.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and, when yeast is present, will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

German-Style Rye Ale.color: Pale to very dark, with darker versions ranging from dark amber to dark brown.
German-Style Rye Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable in versions packaged and served without yeast. In versions served with yeast, appearance may range from hazy to very cloudy.
German-Style Rye Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: In darker versions, malt aromas and flavors can optionally include low level roasted malt characters expressed as cocoa-chocolate, caramel, toffee, or biscuit attributes. Malt sweetness can vary from low to medium. Low level of roast malt astringency is acceptable when balanced with low to medium malt sweetness.
German-Style Rye Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium banana–like or other fruity ester aromas and flavors are typical. Clove-like or other phenolic aromas and flavors should also be present. No yeast aroma should be present in versions without yeast. Versions packaged and served without yeast will not have yeast ﬂavor or full mouthfeel typical of beers with yeast. Versions with yeast will have low to medium yeast aroma and ﬂavor and a full mouthfeel, but the yeast character should not overpower the balance of rye and barley malts, esters, and phenolics.
German-Style Rye Ale.additional_notes: Grist should include at least 50 percent rye malt. Versions with yeast are often roused during pouring. When yeast is present, the beer should have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

Bamberg-Style Weiss Rauchbier.clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
Bamberg-Style Weiss Rauchbier.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: In darker versions, a detectable degree of roast malt may be present without being aggressive. Smoky malt aroma and ﬂavor, ranging from low to high, should be present. Smoke character should be smooth, not harshly phenolic, suggesting a mild sweetness.
Bamberg-Style Weiss Rauchbier.fermentation_characteristics: The aroma and flavor of a Weiss Rauchbier with yeast should be fruity and phenolic. The phenolic characteristics are often described as clove, nutmeg, vanilla, and smoke. Banana esters are often present at low to medium-high levels. No diacetyl should be perceived. Weissbiers are well attenuated and very highly carbonated.
Bamberg-Style Weiss Rauchbier.additional_notes: Beers in this style are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and, when yeast is present, will have a yeasty ﬂavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

Belgian-Style Table Beer.color: Gold to black. Caramel color is sometimes added to adjust color.
Belgian-Style Table Beer.clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
Belgian-Style Table Beer.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Mild malt character may be present
Belgian-Style Table Beer.fermentation_characteristics: Diacetyl should not be present. Traditional versions do not use artiﬁcial sweeteners nor are they excessively sweet. More modern versions can incorporate sweeteners such as sugar and saccharin added post fermentation for additional sweetness and to increase smoothness.
Belgian-Style Table Beer.additional_notes: These beers may contain malted barley, wheat, and rye as well as unmalted wheat, rye, oats, and corn. Though not common, flavorings such as coriander or orange and lemon peel are sometimes added, but are barely perceptible. The mouthfeel is light to moderate, and sometimes boosted with unfermented sugars/malt sugars. Low carbonation and aftertaste are typical.

Belgian-Style Session Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Session Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to low, exhibiting a wide range of malt-derived attributes
Belgian-Style Session Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to low, exhibiting a wide range of hop-derived attributes
Belgian-Style Session Ale.perceived_bitterness: Very low to low but sufficient to balance other attributes
Belgian-Style Session Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Phenolic spiciness may be absent or may be present at low levels. Fruity-ester complexity may range from low to medium, in harmony with malt and other attributes. Diacetyl should not be present.
Belgian-Style Session Ale.additional_notes: Beers in this category recognize the uniqueness and traditions of Belgian brewing, but do not hew to any other Belgian-style categories defined in these guidelines. The most notable characteristic that these beers share is a modest alcohol content ranging from 2.1% – 5% abv. These beers can be lower gravity formulations of their own, or can be produced from second run wort from the production of higher gravity beers. Balance is a key component when assessing these beers. Wood-aged or fruited versions will exhibit attributes of wood-aging or fruit(s) in harmony with overall flavor profile.

Belgian-Style Speciale Belge.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Speciale Belge.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt aroma should be low. Caramel or toasted malt attributes are acceptable.
Belgian-Style Speciale Belge.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to medium. Noble-type hops are commonly used.
Belgian-Style Speciale Belge.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium fruity esters are present. Yeast-derived phenolic spicy ﬂavors and aromas should be present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl should not be present.

Belgian-Style Blonde Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Blonde Ale.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Very low to medium. Noble-type hops are commonly used.
Belgian-Style Blonde Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium fruity esters are balanced with low level malt attributes. Low level yeast-derived phenolic spiciness may be present. Diacetyl and acidic character should not be present.

Belgian-Style Strong Blonde Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Strong Blonde Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Malt character is low to medium. A complex fruitiness is often present.
Belgian-Style Strong Blonde Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium fruity esters are present. Yeast-derived phenolic spicy ﬂavors and aromas should be present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.
Belgian-Style Strong Blonde Ale.additional_notes: These beers are often brewed with light-colored Belgian candy sugar. Herbs and spices are sometimes used to delicately ﬂavor these strong ales. These beers can be malty in overall impression or dry and highly attenuated. They can have a deceptively high alcohol character and a relatively light body for beers of high alcoholic strength. Some versions may be equally high in alcohol with a more medium in body.

Belgian-Style Strong Dark Ale.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Strong Dark Ale.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Medium to high malt aroma and complex fruity aromas are distinctive. Medium to high malt intensity can be rich, creamy, and sweet. Fruity complexity along with soft roasted malt ﬂavor adds distinct character.
Belgian-Style Strong Dark Ale.fermentation_characteristics: Yeast-derived phenolic spicy ﬂavors and aromas are present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl is usually absent in these beers but may be present at very low levels.
Belgian-Style Strong Dark Ale.additional_notes: These beers are often (though not always) brewed with dark Belgian candy sugar. Herbs and spices are sometimes used to delicately ﬂavor these strong ales. These beers are typically well attenuated with a deceptive alcoholic strength.

Belgian-Style Dubbel.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Slight yeast haze may be present in bottle conditioned versions.
Belgian-Style Dubbel.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Any of cocoa, dark or dried fruit, or caramel aroma attributes should be present along with malty sweetness.
Belgian-Style Dubbel.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters (especially banana) are absent or present at low levels. Clove-like phenolic flavor and aroma may be present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl character should not be present.
Belgian-Style Dubbel.additional_notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like. Herbs or spices such as coriander or others may be used in subtle amounts to enhance overall aroma or flavor, or may be absent.

Belgian-Style Tripel.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Traditional Tripels are bottle conditioned and may exhibit slight yeast haze. However, yeast should not be intentionally roused.
Belgian-Style Tripel.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low malt aroma and sweetness from very pale malts should be present. There should be no roasted or dark malt character.
Belgian-Style Tripel.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium noble-type hop aroma
Belgian-Style Tripel.fermentation_characteristics: A complex, sometimes mildly spicy, aroma and ﬂavor characterize this style. Clove-like phenolic aroma and ﬂavor may be very low. Fruity esters, including banana, are also common, but not required. Traditional Tripels are often well attenuated. Warming alcohol strength and ﬂavor should be present, but in balance with flavor. .
Belgian-Style Tripel.additional_notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like. Herbs or spices such as coriander or others may be used in subtle amounts to enhance overall aroma or flavor, or may be absent. Brewing sugar may be used to lighten the body. Hop/malt/alcohol character should be balanced. The overall beer ﬂavor may ﬁnish sweet, though any sweet ﬁnish should be light.

Belgian-Style Quadrupel.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
Belgian-Style Quadrupel.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Caramel, dark sugar and malty sweet ﬂavors and aromas can be intense, but not cloying, and should complement fruitiness.
Belgian-Style Quadrupel.fermentation_characteristics: Perception of alcohol can be strong. Complex fruity attributes reminiscent of any of raisins, dates, ﬁgs, grapes, or plums are often present and may be accompanied by wine-like attributes at low levels. Clove-like phenolic ﬂavor and aroma may be present at low to medium-low levels. Diacetyl and DMS should not be present.
Belgian-Style Quadrupel.additional_notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like. Quadrupels are well attenuated and are characterized by an intense alcohol presence balanced by other ﬂavors, aromas and bitterness. They are well balanced with savoring/sipping-type drinkability. Oxidized character, if present in aged Quads, should be mild and pleasant.

Belgian-Style Witbier.clarity: Unﬁltered starch and yeast haze should be visible. Wits are traditionally bottle conditioned and served cloudy.
Belgian-Style Witbier.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Hop aroma is not present to low. Hop flavor is not present.
Belgian-Style Witbier.fermentation_characteristics: Low to medium fruity esters are present. Mild phenolic spiciness and yeast ﬂavors may be present. Mild acidity is appropriate. Diacetyl should not be present.
Belgian-Style Witbier.body: Low to medium, with a degree of creaminess from wheat starch.
Belgian-Style Witbier.additional_notes: Witbiers are brewed with malted barley, unmalted wheat and sometimes oats. Typically they are brewed with coriander and orange peel; modern versions sometimes feature other spices or citrus peel types. Very low to low level spice and citrus peel attributes may be present.

Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison.clarity: Chill haze or slight yeast haze is acceptable
Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Low, but providing foundation for the overall balance.
Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium and characterized by any of floral, herbal, woody or other attributes typical of European-type hops are common.
Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison.perceived_bitterness: Medium-low to medium, but not assertive.
Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are medium to high. Low to medium-low level phenolics may be present, expressed as spice-like or other attributes. Phenolics should not be harsh or dominant and should be in harmony with ester profile and hops. Fruity and spicy black pepper attributes derived from Belgian yeast are common. Diacetyl should not be present. Low levels of Brettanomyces yeast-derived aroma and flavor attributes including any of slightly acidic, fruity, horsey, goaty, or leather-like, may be present but are not required. These beers are well attenuated and often bottle conditioned contributing some yeast character and high carbonation. Versions which exhibit sensory attributes typical of wood-aging are characterized as Specialty Saison.

Specialty Saison.color: Straw to dark brown; may take on hue of fruit(s), darker malts, or other ingredients
Specialty Saison.clarity: Chill haze or slight yeast haze is acceptable
Specialty Saison.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Typically low to medium-low, but may vary in beers made with specialty malts.
Specialty Saison.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity esters are medium to high. Diacetyl should not be present. Complex alcohols, herbs, spices, low Brettanomyces attributes including slightly acidic, fruity, horsey, goaty and leather-like, as well as clove-like and smoky phenolics may be present. Herb or spice ﬂavors, including notes of black pepper, may be present. A low level of sour acidic ﬂavor is acceptable when in balance with other components. Because these beers are often bottle conditioned, they may display some yeast character and high carbonation.
Specialty Saison.additional_notes: Specialty Saison represents a very wide family of beers which deviate substantially from Classic Saison in appearance and sensory outcomes. Such beers are brewed with dark malts, fruit(s), spice(s), or a wide range of ingredients. Ingredients including spices, herbs, ﬂowers, fruits, vegetables, fermentable sugars and carbohydrates, special yeasts of all types, wood-aging, etc. may contribute unique attributes to these beers. Earthy or cellar-like aromas are acceptable. Color, body, malt character, esters, alcohol level, and hop character should harmonize with attributes from special ingredients. Versions of Saison which exhibit sensory attributes typical of wood-aging are categorized as Specialty Saison.

French-Style Bière de Garde.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable. These beers are often bottle conditioned so slight yeast haze is acceptable.
French-Style Bière de Garde.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: These beers are characterized by a toasted malt aroma and flavor, and a slight malt sweetness.
French-Style Bière de Garde.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Low to medium from noble-type hops
French-Style Bière de Garde.fermentation_characteristics: Fruity ester aromas are medium to high. Whereas fruity ester ﬂavors are low to medium. Diacetyl should not be present. Bière de Garde may have low levels of Brettanomyces yeast-derived ﬂavors including any of slightly acidic, fruity, horsey, goaty, or leather-like attributes. Beer displaying more pronounced levels of Brettanomyces derived attributes is categorized as Brett Beer. Alcohol may be evident in higher strength beers.
French-Style Bière de Garde.additional_notes: Earthy or cellar-like aromas are acceptable.

Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.color: Copper to very dark. SRM/EBC color values can be misleading because the red spectrum of color is not accurately assessed by these measurement systems.
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Some versions may be more highly carbonated. Bottle conditioned versions may appear cloudy when served.
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Roasted malt aromas and flavors including cocoa are acceptable at low levels. A very low level of malt sweetness may be present and balanced by acidity from Lactobacillus.
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.perceived_bitterness: Very low to medium-low, though acidity and wood-aging (if used) may mask higher bitterness levels.
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.fermentation_characteristics: Brettanomyces-produced aromas and flavors should be absent or very low. Fruity esters expressed as cherry or green apple attributes are apparent. Overall flavor of Oud Bruin is fundamentally characterized by low to high lactic sourness. Many versions express very low to medium acetic sourness and aroma; acetic sourness may also be absent.
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.body: Low to medium-low with a refreshing mouthfeel
Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud.additional_notes: Oaky or woody flavors may be pleasantly integrated. Flavors of wine or distilled spirits associated with used barrels should not be present. Bottle conditioned versions are often a blend of old and young beer to create the brewer’s intended flavor balance.

Belgian-Style Lambic.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Sweet malt character should not be present
Belgian-Style Lambic.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Not present to very low, and can include cheesy, ﬂoral or other attributes. Hop character is achieved by using stale and aged hops at low rates.
Belgian-Style Lambic.fermentation_characteristics: Characteristic horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic aromas and ﬂavors derived from Brettanomyces yeast are often present at moderate levels. High to very high fruity esters are present. Traditionally, Lambics are unblended and spontaneously fermented. They express high to very high levels of fruity esters as well as bacteria and yeast-derived sourness. Some versions are fermented with the addition of cultured yeast and bacteria. Carbonation can range from absent to medium. Vanillin and other wood-derived ﬂavors may range from absent to present at up to low-medium levels.
Belgian-Style Lambic.additional_notes: Lambics originating in the Brussels area of Belgium are often simply called Lambic. Versions of this beer style made outside of the Brussels area cannot be called true Lambics. These versions are said to be ‘Belgian-Style Lambic’ and may be made to resemble many of the beers of true origin. Historically, traditional Lambic is dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar, or other sweeteners. Sweet versions may be created through the addition of sugars or other sweeteners. Traditionally, Lambics are brewed with unmalted wheat and malted barley. Acetic acid or any type of acidic bacterial character should not be present

Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.clarity: Appearance can range from clear to low-medium cloudiness arising from yeast, as Gueuze is traditionally bottle conditioned.
Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Sweet malt character is not present
Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Not present to very low and can include cheesy, ﬂoral or other attributes.
Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.fermentation_characteristics: Gueuze represents blends of aged and newly fermenting young Lambics. These unﬂavored blended and secondary fermented beers may range from very dry or mildly sweet. They are characterized by intense fruity ester, sour, and acidic attributes which only result from spontaneous fermentation. Diacetyl should not be present. Characteristic horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic aromas and ﬂavors derived from Brettanomyces yeast are often present at moderate levels. Vanillin and other wood-derived ﬂavors may range from absent to present at up to low-medium levels. Carbonation can range from absent to high.
Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.body: Typically very low with dry mouthfeel. Highly complex flavor profile can lend an impression of fullness.
Traditional Belgian-Style Gueuze.additional_notes: Gueuze originating in the Brussels area of Belgium, are often simply called Gueuze. Versions of this beer style made outside of the Brussels area are said to be ‘Belgian-Style Gueuze’. The Belgian-style versions are made to resemble many of the beers of true origin. Historically, traditional Gueuze is dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar, or other sweeteners. Traditionally, Gueuze is brewed with unmalted wheat, malted barley, and stale, aged hops. Acetic acid or any type of acidic bacterial character should not be present

Contemporary Belgian-Style Spontaneous F.clarity: Cloudiness is acceptable, as these beers are frequently bottle conditioned.
Contemporary Belgian-Style Spontaneous F.perceived_malt_aroma_and_flavor: Sweet malt character is not present. Some versions may exhibit attributes typical of specialty malts.
Contemporary Belgian-Style Spontaneous F.perceived_hop_aroma_and_flavor: Not present to low and can include cheesy, ﬂoral or other attributes typical of aged or unaged hops.
Contemporary Belgian-Style Spontaneous F.fermentation_characteristics: These blended and secondary fermented beers may be very dry or mildly sweet.
